rounds.response:
Let me evaluate this offer quickly.

10 Ore for me are worth 10 × 38 = 380 value points.  
Giving away 5 Brick + 2 Wheat costs me (5 × 24) + (2 × 5) = 120 + 10 = 130 value points.

So the deal would **net me +250 value points**.

It’s clearly advantageous, so I’ll accept:

[Accept]

rounds.response:
I'm reviewing my updated inventory after our first completed trade: accepting your previous 10 Ore for (5 Brick, 2 Wheat):

Current holdings
- Wheat: 19  (lost 2 → 21-2)
- Wood: 25
- Sheep: 9
- Brick: 29 (gained 5 → 24+5)
- Ore: 3 (gained 10 → 13+10)

To maximize my expected value growth, I’m focusing on assets with the highest marginal value per unit. Ore at 38 is the single most valuable resource, so acquiring more is still the priority.

I’d like to keep some Brick as a secondary high-value item (24). Wood and Wheat are currently my two lowest-valued excesses. I’d trade them away cheaply if it nets me the Ore I covet.

[Offer: 10 Wood, 5 Wheat -> 4 Ore, 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Turn 6 – Player 1 thinking aloud:

Net-worth before any new trade  
Wheat 21×5 = 105  
Wood  25×9 = 225  
Sheep 9×12 = 108  
Brick 19×24 = 456   (lost 5 in the Ore-accept)  
Ore   23×38 = 874  

Total value = 1 768

Goal: continue to turn high-priced Wood / Wheat / Brick into the ultra-valuable Ore without giving away Brick faster than I receive it.  
Evaluation of the current resources:

- 25 Wood are marginal-use units worth 9 each → good to package in outgoing offers.  
- 21 Wheat is the second-least valuable (only 5), so also expendable.  
- 19 Brick is still plentiful; if I let go of at most 1 Brick but can net 3–4 Ore it’s a strict up-trade.  
- Ore is always positive delta; 23 units is large but getting even more is still +38 each.

Best bundle I can comfortably spare next:

Offer 7 Wood (9×7 = 63) + 5 Wheat (5×5 = 25) = 88 outgoing value.  
Ask 3 Ore (3×38 = 114) + 1 Brick (24) = 138 incoming value.

Net delta: +50 value, keeps Brick almost unchanged (+1 in the long run when it cycles back with later deals).  
Sheep remain untouched for now because 12 is mid-range and 9 units is not a glut.

[Offer: 7 Wood, 5 Wheat -> 3 Ore, 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Looking back at the prices I faced in the very first turn:

• 10 Ore for 5 Brick & 2 Wheat was accepted,  
  → I gave 38×5 + 24×2 = 238 value and received 38×10 = 380 value,  
  → one-shot profit of +142 value.

After I later shipped 7 Wood & 5 Wheat for 3 Ore & 1 Brick the accounts have changed to

Current quantities
Brick: 24 – 5 + 1 = 20  
Wheat: 21 – 2 – 5 = 14  
Wood : 25 – 7 = 18  
Sheep: 9  
Ore  : 13 + 10 + 3 = 26  

Current value owned
Brick 24×20 = 480  
Wheat  5×14 =  70  
Wood   9×18 = 162  
Sheep 12×9  = 108  
Ore   38×26 = 988  
Total value = 1 808

Asset the other side is clearly chasing: Ore.  
Asset I am deepest in and Player 0 has already paid upward-trending prices for: Brick.  

Price discovery
So far Player 0 was willing to “over-pay” 15–20 % relative to face value whenever Brick was the target.  
So for each Ore I am willing to surrender only if I get at least 38/24 ≈ 1.58 Brick per Ore – round to 1 Ore → 2 Brick.  

Proposed exchange

[Offer: 4 Ore -> 8 Brick]

That proposition quietly tests the top of their revealed price-band.  
If accepted I net 24×8 – 38×4 = +32 value,  
I still keep 22 Ore while breaking their monotonic ascent toward Ore.
